channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Sprechen Sie Deutsch und Perl flieÃŸend? MÃ¶chten Sie in London leben?
item.description: Do you speak German, Perl, and passable English? My London-based client is interested in native (or near-native) German speakers who are interested in relocating to London (to join an English-speaking team).

item.title: Live in sunny Oxford, walk to work along the canal, squeaky clean codebase
item.description: Friendly and Perl-committed company based in Oxford who build a very popular software product. They use Catalyst + Starman, DBIx::Class, and are heavily bought in to Moose.

item.title: Problem-solvers for very strong Perl Fintech/Banking team in London
item.description: Very strong Perl team in central London with a reputation for technical excellence and doing things their own way. Expect to be challenged by very bright co-workers who are determined to move fast and break things.

item.title: CPAN Weekly
item.description: This week was about Graph::Easy - creating and rendering directed graphs. Don't miss the next edition!

item.title: Packaging a Perl script and a Perl module
Using the Perl debugger with DBIx::Class
item.description: Ovid shares his tips for using the Perl debugger with DBIx::Class.

item.title: Choosing a Log Level
item.description: Doug takes us through his approach to log levels.

item.title: Groups and the Pull Request Challenge
item.description: I was so happy with the CV Library team's efforts (team bonding that improves CPAN for all of us!) that I wrote this post to try and encourage more dev groups to join the pull request challenge as a team.

item.title: CPAN Pull Request Challenge, March 2017
item.description: For March, the CV Library team was assigned Linux::Unshare in the CPAN Pull Request Challenge. Here Lance describes their evening spent scoffing pizza and working on the dist's one open bug in RT.

item.title: From Perl to Java
item.description: For some very pragmatic and understandable reasons, Caleb made the transition from Perl to Java, and here he shares some of his thoughts on that.

item.title: alienfile
item.description: An Alien distribution is one that relies on a third party library, typically written in C or similar. Here Graham introduces alienfile, a new recipe system for installing the external packages that an Alien distribution depends on.

item.title: CPAN Meta Browser
item.description: Dan has created a simple web-based interface to the CPAN Index (02packages.details.txt) and the PAUSE permissions dump (06perms.txt).

item.title: An introduction to CPAN distribution metadata
item.description: The Perl Toolchain Summit is only possible with support from sponsors. To acknowledge our Platinum and Gold sponsors, we'll be doing a series of blog posts about toolchain topics, each thanking one sponsor. This first post, an introduction to distribution metadata files, is brought to you by FastMail.

item.title: Idiomatic Use of Inline::Python
item.description: More tips from Moritz on using Python from Perl 6.

item.title: Perl 6 IO TPF Grant: Monthly Report (March, 2017)
item.description: Monthly progress report from Zoffix on his TPF grant for Perl 6 I/O routines.

item.title: That Darn Single Quote
item.description: In Perl 4, instead of :: we used ' as a package separator. Jeremy wonders why we haven't dropped support for that from Perl 5.

item.title: berrybrew, the Perlbrew for Windows has been updated
item.description: Berrybrew is a tool for Windows users that can manage installations of multiple versions of Perl, like perlbrew. There's a new version of berrybrew available, and this post summarises the changes.

item.title: P5P Mailing List Summary: March 22nd-27th
item.description: Sawyer's weekly update from the P5P mailing list. One of the changes coming in Perl 5.26 is not including '.' in @INC, the implications of which are still rumbling on.

item.title: Git::Database now supports seven different Git backends
item.description: Philippe has updated his Git::Database module, which lets you query the Git object database. Now it can use any of seven different backend modules.

item.title: Preparing for LWP Hack Night
item.description: Last week Olaf ran an LWP hack night (also announced on b.p.o), and to prepare for it he posted this information about the various CPAN distributions that live in the LWP organisation on github.

item.title: Quick Quack Hack: perl-autoinstall
item.description: Alas, poor Yanick! I knew him, Horatio: a fellow of infinite jest, of most excellent scripting capabilities. He hath blogged a thousand times, and now one time more: a script to run your Perl script, ensuring all dependencies are installed.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description: Miguel Prz (NICEPERL)'s regular lists: Great modules released last week; MetaCPAN weekly report; StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: #297 - Teams and the Pull Request Challenge
item.description:
The development group at CV Library have joined the Pull Request Challenge as a team. This month Lance describes how they got together over pizza to learn about XS distributions and fix a gnarly outstanding bug. Already another group has asked to sign up, so if you're part of a Perl dev group, maybe you could sign up your team too?

Neil
item.dc:subject: list of tags?
